semantic_title: Code Also Note - Two Codes May Be Required Without Sequencing Direction
section_path: Section I > A. Conventions > 17. 'Code also' note

content.full_text: A "code also" note instructs that two codes may be required to fully describe a condition, but this note does not provide sequencing direction. The sequencing depends on the circumstances of the encounter. (Evidence: pg no: 12, L67-L69)
content.summary: Code Also notes indicate two codes may be needed but do not specify sequencing order, which depends on encounter circumstances (Evidence: pg no: 12, L67-L69)
key_concepts: Two codes may be required (Evidence: pg no: 12, L68)
No sequencing direction provided (Evidence: pg no: 12, L68-L69)
Sequencing depends on encounter circumstances (Evidence: pg no: 12, L69)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Code Also note indicates two codes may be required to fully describe condition (Evidence: pg no: 12, L68)
detailed_rules.explanation: Unlike other instructional notes, Code Also does not specify which code should be primary (Evidence: pg no: 12, L68-L69)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Sequencing depends on circumstances of encounter (Evidence: pg no: 12, L69)
detailed_rules.explanation: Provider must determine appropriate sequencing based on encounter focus and circumstances (Evidence: pg no: 12, L69)

workflow_steps: Step 2: Determine if both conditions are present
Step 3: Code both conditions when appropriate
Step 4: Sequence based on encounter circumstances
Step 5: Consider clinical focus for sequencing

best_practices: Code both conditions when Code Also note applies (Evidence: pg no: 12, L68)
Base sequencing on encounter circumstances (Evidence: pg no: 12, L69)
common_mistakes: Coding only one condition when Code Also applies
Assuming specific sequencing when none is provided
tips: Code Also is different from Code First or Use Additional Code
Consider encounter focus for sequencing decisions
implementation_notes: Both codes typically needed for complete picture
